The play is titled "Le Comte d'Essex" by Claude Boyer, published in 1678. The title mentions the Count of Essex, which I recall was a historical figure involved in a significant event in English history—the Essex Rebellion in 1601 against Queen Elizabeth I. This suggests the play might be set around that time.

Looking at the context, the top person mentioned is Coban, appearing several times, but there's no direct reference to the historical period here. The places include Paris and London (Londres), with Paris being prominent in the publication details. However, the presence of "Londres" indicates action might be set in London.

So, combining the title referencing a 1601 event and mentions of London, I can infer the play is set during the Elizabethan era around 1580 to 1620. The location would primarily be London, as that's where the rebellion occurred.
